msgSnippet: ... From: Curt Sampson  ... Refactoring does not necesarily equate to changing interfaces. ... If change is necessary then it is
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Curt Sampson" <yahoo_sucks@...>
>
> This seems to me tantmount to saying that something is wrong with
> agressive refactoring promoted by the XP process.
>

Refactoring does not necesarily equate to changing interfaces.

> I change interfaces all the time, but I consider this to be something
> right, not something wrong. I think my process is good because I don't
> need to consider whether an interface I'm developing now will be
> workable in the future; I just need to get it to work with what I need
> now--a much simpler and faster job--and leave it at that. And it's good
> for my code because it keeps my code smaller, more easily modifiable,
> and less likely to have bugs.

If change is necessary then it is necessary, but in general it is better to
design something right the first time rather than designing something just
good enough to get it to work, then having to cosntantly change it because
you didn't plan the interface or design well.

I think we are talking past each other - or at least I hope so. I have
worked on a lot of legacy code that was designed with the "I just need to
get it to work" attitude and it was a nightmare to debug, extend, maintain
and refactor. When I work on such code I often wind up throwing it out and
writing it over from scratch - if I am allowed to.

There is a continuim ranging from writing sloppy code to writing code by
committee and virtually unchangeable specification. Neither extreme is
desireable in today's world, but in general interfaces should be designed
with care, an eye for reuse and the future - and after an initial period of
discovery should settle down to be relatively stable and unchanging.
Refactoring can then go on mostly behind the facade of the interface - at
the implementation level where the real work is done.

Constantly changing interfaces are code smells; they smell of poor
encapsulation and exposure of things that should be hidden behind the
interface. They smell of poor design consideration with regards to reuse.
They smell of a bad impedance mismatch between various units.

In short, I assert that a well designed interface should not have to change
very often or very much. If you want to go down that old road of constantly
rewriting and redesigning code under the guise of being "agile" then that is
your right. I've BTDT and I prefer to spend a little bit extra time up front
creating a good design that doesn't need costant refactoring - in the long
run that has worked much better for me.

To each their own.

FWIW,
Lauren
